oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, front cover
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Green photograph album with "George W. Puryear" and "U.S. Air Service" painted in black on the front cover.

George W. Puryear joined the 95th Aero Squadron on July 16, 1918. He was taken prisoner on July 26. He escaped from the POW camp at Villingen, Germany, on October 6 and swam across the Rhine River at Landshut, Germany, on October 11, becoming the first American officer in World War I to successfully escape from a German POW camp. After returning to the U.S., he was stationed at Rockwell Field, San Diego, California. He was killed on October 20, 1919, when his plane crashed shortly after take off.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Fourteen photographs of various Air Service pilots. Top left: Irby R. Curry. Top/3rd from left: Frederick H. Morlan. Middle left: J. Loy "Pat" Maloney. Middle right: George W. Puryear. Two of the photographs appear to be of the same person (top row second from left, and bottom row second from right). Two photographs on the bottom row are the same person (2nd and 3rd from left).

Irby Rice "Rabbit" Curry (1894-1918) was from Marlin, Texas and was the quarterback at Vanderbilt University from 1914-1916. Skipping his senior year at Vanderbilt, Curry enlisted in the Air Service in 1917. After completing training in France, he served as a ferry pilot until he was ordered to the 95th Aero Squadron. He and George W. Puryear joined the squadron on the same day, July 16, 1918. Curry was killed in action on August 10, 1918.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two photographs of American POWs at Burg Trausnitz and the envelope of a letter from Mabel Martin of Memphis, Tennessee, to George W. Puryear while he was a POW.

On August 19 or August 20, George W. Puryear was sent by train with eighteen British and six American POWs from Karlsruhe to Landshut, Germany. The trip took two days. The Americans were imprisoned in Burg Trausnitz (a castle dating to the 13th century). The British were imprisoned in a separate camp in town. On September 14, Puryear was transferred with nine other American officers to the POW camp in Villingen, arriving there on September 15. He escaped from Villingen on the night of October 6 and reached Switzerland on October 11. The letter is marked "Opened By Censor" and addressed: "Lieutenant Geo. W. Puryear, 95th Aero Squadron, Group I, American Prisoner of War, Kriegsgefengenenlager [sic] Rastatt, Baden Germany." Puryear had already been moved from Rastatt by the time the letter was sent, so the letter was forwarded to Landshut, and then to Villingen. It presumably arrived at Villingen after his escape because it is also marked "c/o Alfred I. Puryear, A.S. [Air Service], Paris."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 3
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two photographs of George W. Puryear after his escape from a German POW camp. Top right photograph is Puryear with Frank Soviki. Includes a short newspaper clipping and his explanation of the two photographs.

Puryear escaped from the POW camp in Villingen, Germany, on the evening of October 6, 1918. He swam across the Rhine River and reached Switzerland early in the morning of October 11, 1918, becoming the 1st American officer to successfully escape from a German POW camp. Frank Soviki, an enlisted man, also escaped from a German POW camp and reached Switzerland two days before Puryear, becoming the first American soldier to successfully escape a German POW camp.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 4
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three photographs of pilots and crew of the Far West Flight of the Victory Loan war bond drive at Rockwell Field, San Diego, California, on April 2, 1919 (probably a single panoramic photograph cut into sections). The airplane in the middle photograph is a SPAD S.VII (serial number B9914) and the airplane in the bottom photograph is a captured German Fokker D.VII. George W. Puryear is in the middle photograph, second from right. Also two photographs of children. Top right photograph shows a little girl wearing a German "Pickelhaube" spiked helmet.

George W. Puryear joined the 95th Aero Squadron on July 16, 918. He was taken prisoner on July 26, 1918. Other notable squadron members included Quentin Roosevelt (son of President Theodore Roosevelt) and Irby R. Curry. Roosevelt was killed in action on July 14, 1918, two days before Puryear joined the squadron. Irby Rice "Rabbit" Curry was a quarterback on the Vanderbilt University football team from 1914 to 1916. He joined the squadron on the same day as Puryear and was killed in action on August 10, 1918.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 5
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four photographs of unidentified U. S. Army Air Service personnel and one photograph of Winchester Cathedral. Also a drawing of the RMS Aurania and George W. Puryear's boarding pass for sailing to Europe aboard the Aurania.

The RMS Aurania was an ocean liner owned by the Cunard Line. It was completed in 1916 and served as a troopship. The Aurania was torpedoed off the coast of Scotland by the German U-boat UB-67 on February 4, 1918. The Aurania left New York on November 14, 1917 and arrived at Liverpool on December 2, 1917. After spending a week at Winchester, Puryear landed at Le Havre on December 8. He arrived at Issoudon for flight training on December 15 and received his commission on January 8, 1918. He was put on active duty on January 11. He went to Cazaux on March 6.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 7
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Fourteen photographs of various French aircraft and unidentified people. George W. Puryear is sitting in the front seat of the flying boat (middle of the page). He is also in a photograph with two unidentified women (on right). Also pictured is the Caudron R.4 reconnaissance airplane. Individual photograph descriptions: 1) Wreckage of a French Caudron G.4.
2) French Caudron R.4 reconnaissance plane.
3) Unidentified American standing in front of a Caudron G.4.
The Caudron G.4 was a French bomber and reconnaissance plane that entered service in November 1915. It was also used extensively to provide the initial flight training to Allied pilots.
4) French officer in uniform with 3 medals on his chest. Photograph is signed "Ramy."
5) French Donnet-Denhaut DD-2 flying boat. George W. Puryear is sitting in the front seat.
6) Two unidentified women.
7) George W. Puryear with two unidentified women.
8) Unidentified American soldier greeting several unidentified French officers arriving in a small boat.
9) Unidentified boy holding a string of balloons.
10) A motor boat racing across the water.
11) Two unidentified American pilots.
12) Unidentified American with two unidentified women.
13) Possibly a French Donnet-Leveque flying boat with a Hotchkiss machine gun mounted on it.
14) A French Farman MF.11 fitted with pontoons.

Puryear arrived at Issoudon for flight training on December 15, 1917 and received his commission on January 8, 1918. He was put on active duty on January 11. After completing his flight training, he went to Cazaux for aerial gunnery training on March 6.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 8
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Unidentified pilot in the cockpit of a Nieuport 28. Lieutenant William H. Vail standing next to a Nieuport 28 that he probably ferried to the front. Two photographs from the aerial gunnery school at Cazaux. Unidentified American standing next to the tail of a Caudron R.4 reconnaissance airplane.

Puryear arrived at Issoudon for flight training on December 15, 1917 and received his commission on January 8, 1918. He was put on active duty on January 11. After completing his flight training, he went to Cazaux for aerial gunnery training on March 6. He was ordered back to Issoudon on April 6. He was ordered to the American Acceptance Park at Orly (Seine) on May 10 to serve as a ferry pilot. He was ordered to report to the 1st Pursuit Group on July 12 and joined the 95th Aero Squadron on July 16.

William H. Vail served as a ferry pilot at Orly in May 1918. He joined the 95th Aero Squadron on September 28, 1918, and was seriously wounded on November 6. He was recommended for the Medal of Honor.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 9
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Nine photographs of George W. Puryear and unidentified American pilots. The top middle photograph was taken in the Place de la Concorde in Paris. Middle: Frederick H. Morlan and George W. Puryear standing in front of what looks like a large metal storage tank. Individual photograph descriptions:
1.) George W. Puryear standing next to a Nieuport 28 fighter. 2) Four unidentified American pilots standing in the Place de la Concorde in Paris. 3) George W. Puryear standing next to a SPAD S.XIII fighter. 4) Unidentified American pilot standing next to a French Voisin V bomber. 5) Frederick H. Morlan and George W. Puryear standing in front of what appears to be a large storage tank. 6) Unidentified American pilot sitting in the cockpit of a fighter. Note the round mirror attached to the top wing above the cockpit (in order to see if there is an enemy plane behind one). 7) George W. Puryear sitting on the bottom wing of a French Salmson 2 reconnaissance plane. 8) American ground crew preparing a SPAD S.XIII fighter. 9) Unidentified American pilot sitting next to an unidentified woman.

Puryear arrived at Issoudon for flight training on December 15 and received his commission on January 8, 1918. He was put on active duty on January 11. After completing his flight training, he went to Cazaux for aerial gunnery training on March 6. He then served as a ferry pilot from May-July. Puryear reported to the 95th Aero Squadron on July 16 and was taken prisoner by the Germans on July 26. On October 6, he escaped from the POW camp at Villingen, Germany, and he reached Switzerland on October 11. The view in second photograph is looking northeast down the Rue Royale towards the Ã‰glise de la Madeleine. Behind them is the Fontaine des Fleuves (Fountain of River Commerce and Navigation). The building on the left is flying an American flag. On the Rue Royale side of that building (at No. 3 Rue Royale) is the famous Maxim's restaurant, which opened in 1893. It is possible that they were in Paris visiting George's brother Alfred I. Puryear. Alfred was also a lieutenant in the Air Service during the war, but he wasn't a pilot. He joined the Stock Records Sub-Division, Material Division, Supply Section in January 1918. The Material Division was headquartered at 45 Avenue Montaigne in Paris (just a few blocks west of the Place de la Concorde).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 10
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Eight photographs and one postcard on page. George W. Puryear with an unidentified woman. Two of the unidentified woman. Two of the unidentified woman with Alfred I. Puryear. Unidentified monument. One postcard of an aerodrome at Pontlevoy, France. George W. Puryear next to a SPAD S.XI reconnaissance airplane. Unidentified pilot next to a Salmson 2 reconnaissance airplane. Individual photograph descriptions:
1) George W. Puryear & unidentified woman standing at the base of the Eiffel Tower. 2-3) Unidentified woman (the same woman in photographs 1-5). 4) Unidentified woman with Alfred I. Puryear. For brothers who were born 5 years apart, George & Alfred looked remarkably similar, so it is often difficult to tell them apart in the photographs. Note that the woman is wearing the same dress as in photograph 1, but there are no pilot's wings on Alfred's uniform. He did not earn his pilot's wings until 1921. 5) Unidentified woman with Alfred I. Puryear. 6) Picture postcard of the aerodrome at Pontlevoy, France & addressed to Lt. H. V. Harding. Presumably, the two photographs attached to the postcard are of Lt. Harding. 7) George W. Puryear standing next to a SPAD S.XI two-seat (or "biplace") reconnaissance airplane. 8) Unidentified Army Air Service pilot standing next to a Salmson 2 reconnaissance airplane.

George W. Puryear served as a ferry pilot based at the American airfield at Orly (Seine) from May-July 1918. Alfred I. Puryear joined the Stock Records Sub-Division, Material Division, Supply Section, Army Air Service in January 1918. The Material Division was located in a building at 45 Avenue Montaigne in Paris.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 12
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Condolence letter from the commanding officer of the 9th Aero Squadron informing Fannie W. Puryear of George W. Puryear's death in an airplane accident.

It is unknown exactly when George joined the 9th Aero Squadron at Rockwell Field in San Diego, California There is a postcard from Alfred which is addressed to George there; it is dated February 22, 1919. From April-May 1919, George was a pilot with the No. 3 (Far West) Flight of the Victory Loan war bond campaign. He suffered a broken leg, broken jaw, and skull fracture in the accident on October 20. Flight A's airfield at El Centro was later named Puryear Field.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 13
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Aerial photograph of Chateau-Thierry (looking north) and showing the Marne River.

The area around Chateau-Thierry was the scene of extensive fighting during the Second Battle of the Marne (July 15-August 6, 1918) and the Allies' Aisne-Marne Offensive (July 18-August 6, 1918). A copy of this photograph can also be found in "Gorrell's History of the American Expeditionary Forces Air Service, 07/05/1917 - 08/31/1919," Series M, Volume 39, p. 17.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 14
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eight photographs of unidentified Air Service pilots and ground crew. The SPAD S.XIII in the top right photograph bears the insignia of the 93rd Aero Squadron. The SPAD S.XIIIs in the top/middle (with Lieutenant J. Loy "Pat" Maloney) and both middle; row photographs bear the insignia of the 94th Aero Squadron. The airplane in the bottom left photograph is a Morane-Saulnier Type P monoplane. The airplane in the bottom middle photograph is a SPAD S.XIII.

George W. Puryear flew with the 95th Aero Squadron from July 16 until his capture on July 26. Since the 94th and 95th Aero Squadrons were both stationed at the same airfields throughout the war, these photographs were possibly taken during those 10 days. The famous American ace, Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, flew with the 94th Aero Squadron.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 15
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two photographs on page. Top: George W. Puryear standing next to a SPAD S.VII. He is wearing a flight helmet, goggles, and a leather flight jacket. The number "1374" is written in chalk on the airplane and probably represents the serial number "B1374." Bottom: Aerial photograph of an American airfield in France (possibly at Saints, France).

George W. Puryear flew with the 95th Aero Squadron from July 16 until his capture on July 26. While Puryear was with the 95th, the squadron was flying from an airfield at Saints, France (about 32 miles ESE of Paris).

When an airplane was disassembled for shipment between stations, the serial number of the airplane was chalked on the separate parts. If the SPAD in the photograph is serial number B1374, it would later be shipped to Ellington Field (Houston, Texas) for use by the Mid-West Flight of the Victory Loan war bond drive. The small black characters are thought to identify the painting specifications.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 16
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Aerial photograph (looking North) showing war damage to the French towns of Fismes and Fismette on the Vesle River. Fismes is on the south side of the river and Fismette is on the north side. The town of Blanzy-les-Fismes can be seen in the top left of the photograph.

On the night of August 6-7, the 112th Infantry Regiment, 28th Infantry Division, began its attack on the German troops in Fismette. After weeks of intense fighting, Fismette was declared under American control on August 22. On August 27, the Germans attacked and recaptured the town. The German artillery barrage destroyed the stone bridge over the Vesle between Fismes and Fismette (photograph shows destroyed bridge). Fismette was recaptured by the Americans on the night of September 3-4.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 17
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Left: George W. Puryear's ID photograph taken at the POW camp in Villingen, Germany. Top and bottom: Burg Trausnitz in Landshut, Germany, site of POW camp for American prisoners. Right: 1st Lieutenant Caxton H. "Tich" Tichenor wearing insignia of an observer; pilot (only one wing on insignia, as opposed to a pilot's two wings). Taken at the POW camp in Villingen, Germany. Tichenor was an observer pilot with the 96th Aero Squadron and was taken prisoner on July 10, 1918.

On August 19, 1918 or August 20, 1918, George W. Puryear was sent by train with eighteen British and six American POWs from Karlsruhe to Landshut, Germany. The trip took two days. The Americans were imprisoned in Burg Trausnitz. On September 14, 1918, Puryear was transferred with 9 other American officers (including Lieutenant Tichenor) to the camp in Villingen, arriving there on September 15, 1918 (when his ID photo was taken). He and Tichenor escaped from the Villingen POW camp on the night of October 6, 1918 with eleven other officers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 18
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Four postcards of Bern, Thun, Geneva, and Montreux, Switzerland. Individual photograph descriptions: 1) Postcard of Bern, Switzerland (looking S.E.) showing the railroad bridge (foreground) & granary bridge (KornhausbrÃ¼cke, background) over the Aare River. The Stadttheater (city theater) is visible on the right at the foot of the KornhausbrÃ¼cke. To the left of the Stadttheater is the tower of Bern Cathedral (Berner MÃ¼nster) & further to the left is the tower of the Church of St. Peter & Paul. Various mountain peaks in the background are identified & their elevations (in meters) are given.
2) Postcard of Thun, Switzerland (looking S.E.) showing Thun Castle & the Jungfrau (mountain peak on the left).
3) Business card of Ralph E. Bailey, American Red Cross, signed by Capt. Davis, Assistant M.[ilitary] Attache.
4) Business card of Lieutenant V. O. Meyer, Defense Battalion I/6, 38 Lindenstrasse, Zurich. Meyer was, presumably, the Swiss Army officer detailed to assist George W. Puryear after his arrival in Switzerland.
5) Business card of Robert S. Doman, American Red Cross.
6) Postcard of Geneva, Switzerland, showing the Brunswick Monument & looking S.E. across Lake Geneva towards Mont-Blanc.
7) Postcard of Montreux, Switzerland, looking S.E. across Lake Geneva towards the peaks of the Dents du Midi ("Teeth of the South").

Around 10:30 pm on October 6, the American POWs at Villingen began their mass escape attempt. Puryear swam across the Rhine River at Waldshut, Germany, beginning about 5:00 am on October 11. After being taken to a nearby Swiss Army base, a Swiss Army lieutenant escorted him to Zurich and then on to Bern. He arrived in Bern on October 12 and was contacted by the U. S. Asst. Military Attache. On October 14, he applied for and was issued an emergency passport by the American Embassy in Bern.

Puryear sitting atop a seawall at an unidentified beach resort (possibly southern France); unidentified woman. Bottom row: two photos of George W. Puryear being filmed by the Signal Corps.

George W. Puryear returned briefly to the 95th Aero Squadron in October 1918. Harold Buckley wrote in his book "Squadron 95": "And Puryear, fresh from his marvelous escape from Germany, came back and told us all about it. He did not remain however and was sent from one squadron to another to report on his experience as a prisoner for the benefit of any who might be captured in the future." (145) The caption of U. S. Army Signal Corps film #13358 reads: "Lth. 2.1 M - 7 ft - Several officers leaving the building with Lieut. George W. Puryear. 2nd Aviation Instruction Center. TOURS, Indre-et-Loire, France. 10/23/18." (Gorrell's History of the American Expeditionary Forces Air Service, 07/05/1917 - 08/31/1919, Series M, Volume 5, p. 5) The caption of U.S. Army Signal Corps film #13359 reads: "Lth. 7.6 M - 25 ft - Close up of Lieut. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 20
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four photographs on page. two photographs of unidentified beach resort. Two photographs of American officers Pat O'Brien, Harold Willis, George W. Puryear, and unidentified American officer (formerly in Serbian Army). O'Brien is wearing British pilot's uniform, Willis is wearing French pilot's uniform, Puryear is wearing American pilot's uniform, and unidentified officer is presumably wearing Serbian Army uniform.

Note with photographs states that the portraits were taken at a dinner party in Paris in late October 1918. Harold Willis flew with the Lafayette Escadrille and was shot down on August 18, 1917. He also took part in the mass escape attempt from Villingen with twelve other officers, including George W. Puryear. Willis and Edouard Izac, a U.S. Naval officer, swam across the Rhine and reached Switzerland a day after Puryear. The three were the only ones not recaptured.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 27
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Seven photographs on page. Individual photograph descriptions: 1) A Packard-Le PÃ©re LUSAC-11 fighter plane in flight.
2) Aerial photograph of North Island looking southeast and showing Naval Air Station North Island and Rockwell Field. San Diego is to the left across the bay. Coronado is behind North Island and the Hotel del Coronado is just out of the picture on the right.
3) A Curtiss JN-4 "Jenny" flying over the coast, probably near San Diego.
4) Army Air Service personnel gathered around a wrecked JN-4, probably at Rockwell Field. 5) Unidentified Army Air Service observer pilot sitting in the rear cockpit of a JN-4 in flight. North Island, Coronado, and San Diego Bay are visible behind the tail of the airplane.
6) A dog standing next to the wreckage of a JN-4, probably at Rockwell Field.
7) Unidentified Army Air Service pilot in the cockpit of his airplane.

Naval Air Station North Island and the Army Air Service's Rockwell Field were both located on North Island until 1935 when Rockwell Field closed and the Naval Air Station took over the entire island. The body of water separating North Island from Coronado was called the Spanish Bight. It was filled in by the U. S. Navy in 1943. On February 27, 1920, Major Rudolph W. Schroeder set the flight altitude record in a LUSAC-11 by climbing to 10,093 m (33,113 ft). The Packard-Le PÃ©re LUSAC-11 was based on a French design but was built in the U. S. during World War I. The Army Air Service ordered 3,525 of the airplanes, but the orders were canceled at the end of the war. Only 30 were actually built. On February 27, 1920, Major Rudolph W. Schroeder set the flight altitude record in a LUSAC-11 by climbing to 10,093 m (33,113 ft).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 28
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four photographs and one postcard on page. Postcard shows the Arrowhead Hot Springs Hotel (1905-1938). Top: Unidentified woman (possibly Faye Hughes). Left: Unidentified woman (possibly Faye Hughes) with George W. Puryear in uniform. Right: Unidentified woman; (possibly Faye Hughes) with a dog. Bottom: Unidentified landscape photograph (possibly around San Bernardino).

On February 14, 1920 (approximately four months after George Puryear's death), his mother received a letter from Faye Hughes of 1721 Arlington Avenue, Los Angeles, California She wrote that she met George in San Diego in September 1919, that they spent a lot of time together, and that he came to visit her after she went home in October. She also wrote that, if his squadron was being shipped to the Philippines, they were planning on getting married before he left.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 30
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eight photographs on page. Top left: SPAD Crew No. 2 standing next to SPAD B9913. Left to right: Ira W. Ott, unknown, Lieutenant C. W. Getchell, unknown, and Chauffeur 1st Class Emil Forst. Top right: Curtiss Crew No. 1 standing next to an airplane bearing the insignia of the 103rd Aero Squadron. This airplane was used for photographing the airshows put on by the Far West Flight of the Victory Loan war bond drive. Left to right: 2nd Lieutenant H. M. Wirt, unknown, Sergeant 1st Class Harry R. Duncan, unknown, and unknown. Middle left and middle: Two photographs showing Curtiss JN-4s lined up at an airfield and in flight. Middle right: George W. Puryear, Maks Dembinski, George Higbee, and "Dutch" McCroskey standing next to a Fokker D.VII, serial number 8542. Bottom middle: SPAD crew standing next to SPAD B9911, possibly in Sparks, Nevada. Left to right: Corporal Harold A. Park, Chauffeur James F. Rogers, Chauffeur Clark D. Grove, Captain William J. Hoover, Chauffeur Charles B. Henry, and Master Signal Electrician (MSE) Virgil V. Ullom. Bottom right: SE-5 Crew poses with SE-5 9074. Left to right: Private John Brown, Sergeant 1st Class John Caswell, Lieutenant J. M. Read, William J. Furlong, and Private Edward Coffany.

The 103rd Aero Squadron was formed in February 1918. The first pilots in the squadron came from the disbanded Lafayette Escadrille and Lafayette Flying Corps (American volunteer pilots who flew for the French). The squadron's insignia was the same as the insignia used by the Lafayette Escadrille. In April 1924, the 103rd was consolidated with the 94th Aero Squadron ("Hat in the Ring"). The unit is now known as the 94th Fighter Squadron and is based at Langley Air Force Base, Virginia.

Photographs 1, 2, and 5-8 were taken during the Victory Loan war bond drive, April-May 1919. Puryear was a pilot with the No. 3 (Far West) Flight of the Victory Loan tour. The Far West Flight traveled through California, Nevada, Utah, Idaho, Washington, Oregon, Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, Texas, and Arizona putting on air shows to encourage people to buy war bonds. The commanding officer was Major Carl A. Spaatz, who later commanded the U. S. Army Air Force in the European Theater during World War II. He became the first Chief of Staff of the U.S. Air Force. On April 12, 1919, Puryear flew a Fokker D.VII in the air show at San Francisco, California, for the Victory Loan tour and a photograph of him flying the D.VII appeared the next day in the San Francisco Chronicle newspaper. He is quoted in the accompanying article giving a fantastical account of his escape. On April 15, 1919, he participated in an air show at Reno, Nevada, for the Victory Loan tour.

Spad B9911 had a white nose ring and landing gear struts. The fuselage was also over-painted, obliterating the roundel. It lacks any windshield. Lieutenant Colonel William Thaw flew this airplane in air show at San Francisco, California. Captain Hoover flew it over Sacramento, California, and Reno, Nevada. Captain Lowell Smith would turn it on its back due to a forced landing in Portland, Oregon.

First row left to right: Conrad, Roselle, Munro, Jones, Curran, unknown, McCroskey, Huyck, Duncan, Rogers, Lohman, Boehmer, Leech, Forst, Seals, Haverly, Gould, and Pace. Last row left to right: Higbee, Collins, Madden, Captain Dennis, Major Spatz, Major Marr, Captain Smith, Captain Hoover, Lieutenant Folmer, Lieutenant Cavanagh[?], Lieutenant Andrews, unknown, Lieutenant Wirt, Lieutenant Puryear, Lieutenant Atkins, Lieutenant McMullen, Lieutenant Getchell, Lieutenant McClain, Lieutenant Halverson, Lieutenant Miller, unknown, Master Signal Electrician Ullom, and Coffaney. The building behind the tracks has a sign painted across the top which reads "Pocatello Produce Packing Co." Middle right bottom: Four African American and one European American railroad employees. M. Atkins and crew pose with his SE-5a C9077. From left to right: Lieutenant Atkins, Chauffeur Bennie Collins, Private George K. Basham, Bertram Wrede, and Sergeant 1st Class Elliott F. Leech. Bottom right: 1st Lieutenant Harold W. Follmer and crew standing next to Fokker 8541 (not their airplane). Left to right: Private 1st Class Floyd Eaton, Sergeant 1st Class Jerry M. Wickliffe, Lieutenant Follmer, Private Albert F. Madden, and Private 1st Class Francis J. McCloskey.

Puryear was a pilot with the No. 3 (Far West) Flight of the Victory Loan war bond drive during April-May 1919. The Far West Flight traveled through California, Nevada, Utah, Idaho, Washington, Oregon, Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, Texas, and Arizona; putting on air shows to encourage people to buy war bonds. On April 13, 1919, a photograph of Puryear flying a Fokker D.VII in the air show at San Francisco, California appeared in the "San Francisco Chronicle" newspaper.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 32
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Twp photographs on page. Top: Crowd watching Lieutenant Colonel William Thaw sitting in the cockpit of SPAD B9911 at San Francisco, California, on April 12, 1919. Ornamental statues salvaged from the Panama-Pacific International Exposition (1915) form the boundary of the roadway. The view is toward the Golden Gate. Bottom: Crowd watching three Fokker D.VIIs being prepared for takeoff.

Puryear was a pilot with the No. 3 (Far West) Flight of the Victory Loan war bond drive during April-May 1919. The Far West Flight travelled through California, Nevada, Utah, Idaho, Washington, Oregon, Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, Texas, and Arizona putting on air shows to encourage people to buy war bonds. On April 13, 1919, a photograph of Puryear flying a Fokker D.VII in the air show at San Francisco, California appeared in the "San Francisco Chronicle" newspaper.

SPAD B9911 was unique in having the British roundel painted out on the fuselage sides, and the roundels on the wings repainted in American colors of red outer, blue middle, and white center. The nose, landing gear, wheels, and gas tank were also painted white. This SPAD was later wrecked in Portland, Oregon, when the propeller broke while Captain Lowell Smith was performing stunts over the city.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 33
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three photographs on page. Top left: Lieutenant Leland Miller, photographic officer for the Far West Flight of the Victory Loan war bond drive, standing in the front seat of an airplane and holding a box camera used for aerial photography. Bottom left: Unidentified Army Air Service pilot sitting in the cockpit of a Fokker D.VII.; Right: Lieutenant Colonel William Thaw II wearing a leather flight jacket.

William Thaw II flew with the French Air Force beginning in 1915. He later transferred to Escadrille 124, the unit of volunteer American pilots nicknamed the Lafayette Escadrille. The unit was disbanded after the U. S. entered the war and Thaw became commanding officer of the 103rd Aero Squadron. He was also one of the pilots of the No. 3 (Far West) Flight of the Victory Loan war bond drive during April-May 1919.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 34
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Six photographs on page. Top: Army Air Service pilots (Far West Flight of the Victory Loan war bond drive). George W. Puryear is third from right and Lieutenant Colonel William Thaw II is 4th from right. Middle left: SPADs B9911 (left) and B9913 (right) being prepared for the air show at Reno, Nevada, on April 15 1919. Mt. Rose is faintly visible in the background. The roundels on the wing of B9911 have been repainted in American colors while those on B9913 remain in their British colors as delivered. Middle middle: Unidentified ground crew standing next to a Fokker D.VII (before the bottom wing has been attached). Middle right: Lieutenants Follmer and Puryear getting dressed for a flight. Follmerâ€™s Fokker 8539 is in the immediate background. Another photo taken in the same setting shows two more Fokkers, Lt. Puryearâ€™s 8541 and the spare 8542 in the background, indicating that the location is Rockwell Field, probably on April 7, when the airplanes were being tested prior to being loaded on the train the next day. There is no other case where these three machines would have been seen together. Bottom: Two photographs of the train used by the Far West Flight of the Victory Loan war bond drive stopped on railroad tracks (left photograph labeled "Between Reno and Salt Lake").

William Thaw II flew with the French Air Force beginning in 1915. He later transferred to Escadrille 124, the unit of volunteer American pilots nicknamed the Lafayette Escadrille. The unit was disbanded after the U. S. entered the war and; Thaw became commanding officer of the 103rd Aero Squadron. He was also one of the pilots of the No. 3 (Far West) Flight of the Victory Loan war bond drive during April-May 1919.

A special cab-forward locomotive had been used to pull the train over the high Sierras between Sacramento, California, and Sparks, Nevada. This was necessary to protect the crew from suffocation in the numerous tight snow sheds and tunnels. However, a conventional locomotive (as seen here) was used for the remainder of the trip.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 35
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Ten photographs and one marriage announcement on page. Wedding announcement for Hilda Gladys Blackburn and Lieutenant J. Loy Maloney with photograph of Lieutenant Maloney. Various scenes from Victory Loan tour through western U. S. 3 photographs of unidentified people; standing next to a Fokker D.VII. Two photographs of Native Americans. Railroad bridge near Great Salt Lake. View of a railroad bridge near the Great Salt Lake. Written on the photograph is: "[illeg.] car of train, Salt Lake."
1) Two Native Americans sitting in a horse-drawn carriage. Behind them is the train used by the Far West Flight of the Victory Loan war bond campaign to travel across the country. 4) First Lieutenant Harold W. Follmer poses with two unidentified spectators beside his Fokker 8539. 5) A Native American woman sitting on a boulder, bent over, and hiding her face from the camera. 6) Chauffeur 1st Class â€œDutchâ€ McCroskey engaging in horseplay with Private 1st Class Maks Dembinski at Boise, Idaho, on April 19, 1919. In a matter of minutes the site would become a beehive of activity as the crews return from â€œdinnerâ€ and prepare for the afternoon show. The site is the south corner of Fort Boise known as the polo grounds. The view is to the northeast. 8) Two Pullman Porters from the Victory Loan train pose by Fokker 8541 at Portland, Oregon. There were three porters, five cooks, and five waiters on the train. One of these two unidentified men was given a ride in a Jenny that day. 9) Two unidentified crew members and Lieutenant McMullen pose with a dark-colored Curtiss (probably the same airplane in #11). 11) 2nd Lieutenant S. E. Cavanagh standing next to a Curtiss airplane. Unidentified insignia showing a smiling bulldog is on the side of the airplane. However, it is believed that this was not Cavanagh's airplane.

Puryear was a pilot with the No. 3 (Far West) Flight of the Victory Loan war bond drive during April-May 1919. The Far West Flight travelled through California, Nevada, Utah, Idaho, Washington, Oregon, Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, Texas, and Arizona; putting on air shows to encourage people to buy war bonds. On April 13, 1919, a photograph of Puryear flying a Fokker D.VII in the air show at San Francisco, California appeared in the "San Francisco Chronicle" newspaper.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 36
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
Eight photographs on page. Various scenes from Victory Loan tour through western U. S. Top right: Major Carl A. Spaatz and Lieutenant Colonel William Thaw II. Middle/left: George W. Puryear, Native American man, and unidentified man standing next to a Fokker D.VII.; Bottom right: "Jerry M. Wickliff Parlier Cal. [and] Geo. G. Higbee Santa Barbara Cal." 1) Five Native Americans of the Shoshone tribe on horseback visiting the flight line at Pocatello, Idaho, on April 18, 1919. Behind is a Curtiss JN-4 with the bulldog insignia.
2) Photograph taken from the window of the front of a train as it travels through rocky hills. It is probably the same location as photograph #7.
3) Major Carl A. Spaatz and Lt. Colonel William Thaw II.
4) George W. Puryear standing with an unidentified Native American man and Idaho Governor David W. Davis (who took office on January 6, 1919) next to Fokker 8541 at Pocatello, Idaho, on April 18, 1919. After the air show, Davis boarded the Far West Flight's train and rode with them to Boise.
5) Photograph of a mountain taken from the moving train.
6) Native Americans among the crowd of people gather to see the Far West Flight of the Victory Loan war bond drive.
7) Photograph taken from the window of the rear of a train as it travels through rocky hills. It is probably the same location as photograph #2.
8) "Jerry M. Wickliff Parlier Cal. [&] Geo. G. Higbee Santa Barbara Cal."

Carl A. Spaatz was the commanding officer of the 13th Aero Squadron during World War I. He was also the commanding officer of the Far West Flight for the Victory Loan war bond drive. He added the 2nd "a" to his last name in 1937 in an attempt to get people to pronounce it correctly ("spahtz"). During World War II, he commanded the 8th Air Force from May to July 1942. On July 7, 1942, he was placed in command of all U. S. Army Air Force units in the European Theater of Operations. In September 1947, he was appointed by President Truman to be the first Chief of Staff of the U. S. Air Force. He retired on June 30, 1948.
William Thaw II enlisted in the French Foreign Legion at the outbreak of World War I. He joined the French Air Force in December 1914 and flew with Escadrille 6, Escadrille 42, and Escadrille 65. He is credited with being the first American to engage in aerial combat in the war. Thaw eventually transferred to Escadrille 124. Escadrille 124 was a squadron composed of American volunteers and was nicknamed the Lafayette Escadrille. After the U. S. entered the war in 1917, the Lafayette Escadrille was disbanded and Thaw became the commanding officer of the 103rd Aero Squadron. He died of pneumonia on April 22, 1934.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description:

Puryear sitting on a wooden bench with two unidentified; women. Fourth row left: George W. Puryear poking at a saguaro cactus. second row middle: Two young members of a Portland, Oregon, girlâ€™s dance troupe (here costumed as aviators) posing with Sergeant 1st Class George G. Higbee and Corporal Maks Dembinski, both members of the crew assigned to Fokker 8541. Bottom/right: A boy and two men standing next to a mine elevator. 1) Unidentified Army Air Service pilot posing with 2 Native American women.
2) A crowd of people hauling a Curtiss JN-4 on a ramp up the railroad siding. The JN-4's wings have been removed in order to reload it onto the train.
3) Army Air Service ground crew standing next to a Fokker D.VII.
4) Army Air Service ground crew working on a Fokker D.VII.

6) George W. Puryear and 2 unidentified women sitting on wooden bench under a tree.
7) George W. Puryear poking at a saguaro cactus (Carnegiea gigantea).
8) Five unidentified people riding in a car.
9) A boy and two men standing next to a mine elevator.

Puryear was a pilot with the No. 3 (Far West) Flight of the Victory Loan war bond drive during April-May 1919. The Far West Flight travelled through California, Nevada, Utah, Idaho, Washington, Oregon, Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, Texas, and Arizona; putting on air shows to encourage people to buy war bonds. On April 13, 1919, a photograph of Puryear flying a Fokker D.VII in the air show at San Francisco, California appeared in the "San Francisco Chronicle" newspaper.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 38
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from George W. Puryear to his mother, Fannie W. Puryear. In it, he describes pilot training and meeting "Quinton" [sic] Roosevelt Lieutenant He tells her not to worry about him. Also glued to the page are copies of the Rudyard Kipling poem "Mother o' Mine." and Corporal L. H. Pillion's poem "What Matters."

George W. Puryear was at Issoudun receiving flight training from 12/15/1917-3/6/1918 and from 4/6/1918-5/10/1918. Quentin Roosevelt was the youngest son of President Theodore RooseveLieutenant He joined the 95th Aero Squadron on June 17, 1918. He was killed in action on July 14, 1918 (two days before Puryear joined the squadron) and was buried with full military honors by the Germans.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 41a
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Temporary emergency passport issued to George W. Puryear after his escape from a German POW camp and his arrival in Bern, Switzerland. The back bears stamps from the American (10/15/1918) and French (10/16/1918) embassies in Bern. There is also a stamp; for his entry into France at Bellegarde (probably Bellegarde-sur-Valserine) on October 17, 1918. Also attached to the back is a small newspaper clipping about his escape.

Puryear escaped from the POW camp at Villingen, Germany, on October 6, 1918. He swam across the Rhine River into Switzerland at Waldshut, Germany, on the morning of October 11. He arrived in Bern on October 12. He applied for and was issued his emergency passport on October 14th.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 42
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three photographs and one document on page. Document was written by George Puryear and is a chronology of his military service from the date he volunteered until he joined the 95th Aero Squadron. Top left: Nieuport 28 fighter bearing the insignia of the 95th Aero Squadron (kicking mule) and #11 on the side. It is captioned, "George's Plane [he was] captured in." Top right: unidentified woman. Bottom left: Possibly George Puryear holding a girl sitting on the fuselage of a Fokker D.VII (Victory Loan war bond drive).

The Nieuport 28 was not the airplane George Puryear was captured in. The 95th Aero Squadron was initially issued Nieuport 28s but had switched over to SPAD S.XIIIs by the time Puryear joined the squadron on July 16, 1918. A copy of the official incident report related to his capture is in Album 3, page 39; it states that he was flying a SPAD S.XIII (factory #15033 and plane #24). However, he may have received flight training in the Nieuport 28.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 44
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two military shoulder patches, one postcard and one photograph. Photograph captioned: "Part of temporary camp, Puryear Field El Centro Cal -- Flight 'A' 91st Aero Sqdn." Same photograph as Album 2, page 45. Postcard stamped Memphis, Tennessee, June 27, 1919. It is from Fernande (no last name) to George Puryear. It was addressed to Memphis, but was forwarded to Rockwell Field, San Diego, California The capital "A" patch is for the U. S. First Army and the red, white, and blue roundel is for the Army Air Service.

The Army Air Service roundel patch was sewn over the crossbar on the "A" of the First Army patch. George W. Puryear was killed shortly after taking off from the airfield at El Centro on October 20, 1919. Some documents say he was taking off from Calexico, California, but the two towns are only a few miles apart.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 45
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of Charles A. Lindbergh sitting in the cockpit of his airplane, the "Spirit of St. Louis," before leaving on his trans-Atlantic flight from New York to Paris. It is captioned, "The one place Col. Charles Augustus Lindbergh feels most at home." The photograph was cut out of an unknown periodical where it appeared after Lindbergh's return to the U. S.

Lindbergh flew from New York to Paris on May 20-21, 1927. He was promoted to colonel on June 7, 1927, after returning home to the U. S. It is unknown who added this photograph to George W. Puryear's album, since Lindbergh's trans-Atlantic flight took place nearly eight years after Puryear was killed in a plane crash on October 20, 1919.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, page 46a
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Vanderbilt University commencement program from 1916. Photograph of George W. Puryear (left) and an unidentified man (both wearing bathing suits). Probably taken in San Diego, California Hawkins School commencement program from 1913. Postcard from Alfred Puryear to George, postmarked Ventimiglia, Italy, February 23, 1919. Postcard from Lieutenant J. L. "Pat" Maloney in France to George Puryear, postmarked January 13, 1919.

George W. Puryear is listed among the law school students in the Vanderbilt University commencement program. The Hawkins School was located in Gallatin, Tennessee, and George Puryear is listed as class president in the commencement program. Alfred Puryear wrote that he had been to Monte Carlo. The postcard is addressed to George at Rockwell Field, San Diego, California Lieutenant Maloney wrote that they flew up to the Rhine River on January 8, 1919.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 1, back cover
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Back cover of Album 1

George W. Puryear joined the 95th Aero Squadron on July 16, 1918. He was taken prisoner on July 26. He escaped from the POW camp at Villingen, Germany on October 6 and swam across the Rhine River at Waldshut, Germany on October 11, becoming the first American officer in World War I to successfully escape from a German POW camp. After returning to the U. S., he was stationed at Rockwell Field, San Diego, California He was killed on October 20, 1919, when his plane crashed shortly after take off.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: World War I discharge guide pamphlet entitled "Where Do We Go From Here? This Is the Real Dope."

Alfred I. Puryear stayed with the Army Air Service in France for nearly a year after the Armistice went into effect on November 11, 1918. He sailed home aboard the U.S.S. Agamemnon on September 16, 1919. He stayed in the Air Service after the war, earned his pilot's wings in 1921, and became an airship pilot. In 1920, he served as supply officer on Captain Rudolph Schroeder's team in the Gordon Bennett Cup Race. He retired from the Air Service in 1933.

Alfred Isaac Puryear was the older brother of George Wright Puryear. He served in the Stock Records Subdivision, Material Division, Supply Section, U.S. Army Air Service, throughout World War I. He stayed in the Air Service after the war, earned his pilot's wings in 1921 and became an airship pilot. In 1920, he served as supply officer on Captain Rudolph Schroeder's team in the Gordon Bennett Cup Race. He retired from the Air Service in 1933 and died in Gallatin, Tennessee, in 1982.

George W. Puryear arrived at Issoudon for flight training on December 15 and received his commission on January 8, 1918. He was put on active duty on January 11. After completing his flight training, he went to Cazaux for aerial gunnery training on March 6. He then served as a ferry pilot from May to July. He reported to the 95th Aero Squadron on July 16 and was taken prisoner by the Germans on July 26. On October 6, he escaped from the POW camp at Villingen, Germany, and he reached Switzerland on October 11.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 17
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three photographs on page. Left: Frederick H. Morlan standing in front of a large storage tank. Middle: Frederick H. Morlan and George W. Puryear standing in front of a large storage tank. Right: George W. Puryear standing; in front of a large storage tank.

George W. Puryear arrived at Issoudon for flight training on December 15 and received his commission on January 8, 1918. He was put on active duty on January 11. After completing his flight training, he went to Cazaux for aerial gunnery training on March 6. He then served as a ferry pilot from May to July. He reported to the 95th Aero Squadron on July 16 and was taken prisoner by the Germans on July 26. On October 6, he escaped from the POW camp at Villingen, Germany, reaching Switzerland on October 11.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 18
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thirteen photographs on page showing various scenes of war damage. Row 1, left: War damage to the Montdidier train station. There are two ambulances (each marked with a red cross) in the bottom/right corner.

The Battle of Montdidier is the name given to the assault by French troops during the Battle of Amiens (August 8-December, 1918). The Battle of Amiens began a series of offensives that led to the end of World War I. The Montdidier train station is still in use.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 19
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two photographs on page showing American graves in and war damage to Belleau, France.

The Battle of Belleau Wood was fought June 1-26, 1918, between various German Army units and the U.S. 2nd and 3rd Infantry Divisions. The 2nd Infrantry Division also included the 5th and 6th Marine Regiments and the 6th Machine Gun Battalion. After nearly a month of ferocious fighting, U.S. troops were finally able to drive the German troops from the woods, at a cost of 9777 casualties, including 1811 killed.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eight daily ration stamps for 100 grams of bread (dated September 1-8). Aerial photograph of an unidentified fort destroyed by artillery fire (possibly in Belgium). Two postcards showing war damage to the Basilica of Notre-Dame de BrebiÃ¨res in Albert, France.

Albert was heavily damaged during the war. The Basilica of Notre-Dame de BrebiÃ¨res had been damaged by shelling in January 1915; the statue of Mary and the infant Jesus atop the basilica was bent to a nearly horizontal position. Many legends subsequently developed about the "Leaning Virgin." The town was also a key location during the Battle of the Somme (July-November 1916).

George W. Puryear was put on active duty and ordered to report to Chicago for flight training on May 18, 1917. On July 9, the flight training school was moved to Rantoul, Illinois. He took his flight training tests on October 16 and received his commission as 2nd lieutenant on November 2. He sailed for Europe aboard the R.M.S. Aurania on November 14 and landed at Liverpool, England, on December 2. He landed at Le Havre, France, on December 8 and arrived at Issoudun for flight training on December 15.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 30
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Clippings from the Paris edition of the Chicago Tribune newspaper. The clippings are all related to the World War I victory celebrations in Paris.

Hostilities ceased when the Armistice went into effect at 11:00 a.m. on November 11, 1918. The five treaties that officially ended the war were drawn up during the Paris Peace Conference from January 18, 1919 to January 21, 1920. The most famous, or infamous, treaty was the Treaty of Versailles, which ended the war with the German Empire; it was signed on June 28, 1919. The World War I victory celebrations in Paris were held on Bastille Day, July 14, 1919.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 36a
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Left: U.S.S. Agamemnon newsletter dated September 26, 1919. Right: Blank stationery from the R.M.S. Adriatic.

Alfred Puryear left for Europe aboard the Adriatic on December 25, 1917. His voyage home aboard the Agamemnon began on September 16, 1919. The Agamemnon was built in 1903 as the S.S. Kaiser Wilhelm II and was operated by Norddeutscher Lloyd. It was seized by the U.S.; after it declared war on Germany in April 1917 it was renamed the Agamemnon in September. Alfred Stieglitz's famous photograph "The Steerage" was taken aboard this ship in 1907. The Adriatic was built in 1907 and was operated by the White Star Line.

The U.S. Army and Navy both used hydrogen-filled balloons and airships until the destruction of Army Airship C-2 on October 17, 1922. Afterwards, they began converting all balloons and airships to use non-flammable helium.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 39
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper clippings related to George W. Puryear's escape from a German POW camp. It also has a photograph of the POW camp.

Puryear was part of a mass breakout from the POW camp that began shortly after 10:30 p.m. on October 6, 1918. He spent the next five days making his way to the Swiss border. He began swimming across the Rhine River from Waldshut, Germany, to Switzerland at 5:00 a.m. on October 11, 1918. Of the thirteen Americans who took part in the escape, only Puryear and two others were successful. He made it to Switzerland a day before the other two, so he was the 1st U.S. officer to successfully escape from a German POW camp during the war.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 44a
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Radiogram from Bern, Switzerland, announcing the news of George Puryear's successful escape. Handwritten note by Alfred Puryear is attached stating that it was given to him at the Daily Mail's editorial office in Paris (10/12/1918). Telegram from the; Red Cross to Alfred informing him that George was a POW at Rastatt (August 20, 1918). Telegram to Alfred from George after his escape (October 14, 1918). Postcard from George to Alfred from the POW camp at Villingen (September 26, 1918).

The clipping attached to the radiogram is a direct translation of most of the news dispatch. The last sentence of the clipping is not in the dispatch. The dispatch also states that George is being hosted by the American Red Cross. The last sentence of the; dispatch quotes George as saying that the situation in Germany is bad and that German soldiers know that their country is beaten.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 46
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Six photographs on page. Top left: George Puryear holding a golf club and standing next to a young African American caddie. Top middle: Unidentified woman and Alfred Puryear at the Eiffel Tower Top Right: George Puryear and friend at the beach. Bottom left: George Puryear and "his best pal" at the beach. Bottom middle: Unidentified woman and Alfred Puryear. Bottom right: Unidentified woman and Alfred Puryear.

George's fiancee, Faye Hughes, wrote to his mother after his death. She described his friend "Chappie," who is possibly the person in the beach photographs. "'Chappie' was a queer chap--much older than George, and not his equal in any way--but he had a heart of gold, he just worshipped George, and we thought a great deal of him. He was 'a diamond in the rough' as George said."

Puryear Family Photograph Albums, approximately 1890-1945; The StÃ¤dtische Festhalle was built from 1898 to 1901. It was severely damaged during an air raid on November 6, 1944. The ruins were demolished on March 11, 1952. Fortress Ehrenbreitstein was built by Prussia from 1817 to 1832. It was occupied by U.S. troops from 1919 to 1923. During World War II, it was captured by the U.S. 69th Infantry Division on March 27, 1945. Stolzenfels Castle was completed in 1259 and was used to protect a toll station on the Rhine.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 50
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three photographs of Mt. Wilson north of Arcadia, Calif. One label from a bottle of "Imperial Whisky."

Arcadia was the site of Ross Field, an Army balloon school. Some sources list the school as closing in 1919, but photographs and documents in this album and Album 3 show that it was still in operation as late as 1921. Alfred Pruyrear went to balloon school; there, beginning in either late 1920 or early 1921. He made his first solo flight on July 8, 1921, flying from Arcadia to Glendora, California.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 51
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eight photographs and 1 clipping on page. Top: two photographs of the Duvall family with Alfred I. Puryear in Belleville, Ill. Middle: two photographs of Lieutenant Williams and Mrs. Williams standing next to a house and two photographs of them in Kapiolani Park, Honolulu.; Bottom left: Army airship TC-9 of the 19th Airship Company based at Langley Field, Va. Bottom middle: Clipping listing the cast of the 1923 silent Western film "The Covered Wagon." Bottom right: two cars parked in front of a house. Photograph is captioned "Magnolia Tree Lane."

Alfred I. Puryear completed his pilot training in 1921 and was stationed at Scott Field, Belleville, Ill., in July 1922. Between 1924 and 1926, he seems to have been transferred back and forth between Scott Field and Langley Field, Virginia. In June 1926 he was assigned to the 19th Airship Company at Langley Field. In February 1928, he assumed command of the 19th Airship Company and on January 17, 1929 was promoted to captain. In June 1930, he was transferred to the 2nd Balloon Company, Fort Bragg, North Carolina, and was its commander until November 30, 1933.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One photograph, two clippings, one postcard, and one envelope on page. Top left: Kathrine [illeg.] at the Leven Oaks Hotel. Roberts in the Democratic primary for the 1920 election and a clipping with a photograph of Colonel Harry S. Berry. Bottom left: postcard from the Leven Oaks Hotel. Bottom right: envelope of a letter from Y. Heuryon, Paris, France, to Alfred I. Puryear, Gallatin, Tennessee, postmarked November 28, 1919.

The Leven Oaks Hotel was a resort hotel built in 1911 and is now an assisted living facility. Monrovia is east of Ross Field, Arcadia, California, where Alfred was stationed for his training to become an airship pilot. He completed his training in December 1921. Nashville International Airport (BNA) was originally named Berry Field in honor of Colonel Harry S. Berry.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 53
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 6 photographs on page. Top left: Alfred I. Puryear with an unidentified woman. Top right: Alfred, holding a dog, with an unidentified man and two unidentified women. Middle left and middle right: Fannie W. Puryear in front of the U.S. Capitol. Bottom left: Unidentified woman sitting in front of the U.S. Capitol. Bottom right: Alfred and his mother, Fannie W. Puryear, sitting in front of the U.S. Capitol.

After returning from France in September 1919, Alfred I. Puryear served in the office of the Chief of the Air Service. The Air Service was headquartered in the Munitions Building on Constitution Avenue in Washington, D.C. It remained there until construction of the Pentagon was completed in 1943. The building was demolished in 1970, and the site is now occupied by the Vietnam Veterans Memorial.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 54
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Six photographs on page. Top left: unidentified man. Top middle: Alfred I. Puryear in Paris and wearing District of Paris shoulder patch. (Note: This photograph was printed reversed. The patch was actually worn on the left shoulder and the Sam Browne belt crossed over the right shoulder.) Top right: Alfred I. Puryear and unidentified woman sitting in a car. Bottom left: Alfred I. Puryear in France. Bottom middle: Alfred I. Puryear and two unidentified women. Bottom right: Alfred I. Puryear in uniform and leaning against a pillar.

Alfred I. Puryear joined the Stock Records Subdivision, Material Division, Supply Section, Army Air Service, in January 1918. The Material Division was located in a building at 45 Avenue Montaigne in Paris. In October 1918, Puryear was promoted to; 1st lieutenant. Air Service records list him with the Stock Records Subdivision as late as November 15, 1918. Stock Records kept track of supplies on hand and distributed requisitioned supplies to the various Air Service units in France.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 55
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three photographs showing the destruction of the U.S. Army Airship C-2.

On October 17, 1922, a strong gust of wind caught the airship C-2 as it was being maneuvered out of its hangar. It struck the hangar door, tearing the "envelope" open and igniting the hydrogen gas inside. After the destruction of the C-2, the U.S. Army and U.S. Navy began converting all of their airships to use non-flammable helium gas.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 57
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three photographs of U.S. Army Airship TC-3 at Brooks Field, San Antonio, Texas. Top right photograph also shows a Curtiss JN-4 (left) and a Curtiss JN-4 (right). Bottom right photograph shows an unidentified service member wearing a parachute.

The TC-3 entered service around late September 1923 & was stationed at Scott Field, Belleville, Illinois. It left for Brooks Field on November 16, 1923 to participate in the Kelly Field Air Carnival for Army Relief and arrived at Brooks Field on Novmeber 17, 1923. It left Brooks Field to return to Scott Field on November 30, 1923. Alfred Puryear was a student pilot aboard the TC-3 for the trip. He completed his initial pilot training at Ross Field, Arcadia, California, in July 1921 and was transferred to Scott Field in August 1922.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 58
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph showing the wreckage of U.S. Army Airship TC-2.

Alfred Puryear completed his initial airship pilot training in July 1921. The airship TC-2 (195 ft. long and 59 ft. high) was engaged in a bombing competition at Langley Field when one of the bombs it was carrying exploded prematurely, causing it to fall 150 ft. to the ground. Two of the five crew members were killed and three wounded. Puryear, the airship's observer, was seriously wounded. He retired from the Air Service in November 1933 due to disability from injuries sustained in this accident.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four photographs on page. Top left: Lieutenant Alfred I. Puryear. The other three photographs show the wreckage of U.S. Army Airship TC-2.

Puryear completed his training to become an airship pilot in July 1921. The airship TC-2 (195 ft. long and 59 ft. high) was engaged in an Air Service bombing competition at Langley Field when one of the bombs it was carrying exploded prematurely, causing it to fall 150 ft. to the ground. Two of the five crew members were killed and three wounded. Puryear, the airship's observer, was seriously wounded. He retired from the Air Service in November 1933 due to disability from injuries sustained in this accident.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 60
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Aerial view of Brooks Field looking northeast. Hangars 15 and 16 are visible on right. Shadow of the Army airship (probably the TC-3) visible in center.

Originally designated Kelly Field No. 5 in December 1917, the airfield was renamed Brooks Field in February 1918. It became the primary Army flight school after World War I and Charles A. Lindbergh was one of its graduates. Of the 16 original aircraft hangars at Brooks Field, Hangar 9 is the only remaining World War I era wooden aircraft hangar in the United States.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 61
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Aerial view of San Antonio, Texas, looking southeast (probably taken from U.S. Army Airship TC-3). The Stowers Furniture Company building, at the intersection of Main and Houston Streets, is in the center. Directly behind the Stowers Building is the Rand Building (1913). Robert E. Lee Hotel (1923) is to left of Stowers Building. The tall building on right edge of photograph is the Frost Bank Building (1922). The Gunter Hotel (1909) and Brady Tower (1913) on Houston St. are on left edge of photograph.

The Frost Bank Building became the Municipal Plaza Building in 1994. In November 1981, a deal was reached between Frost Bank & the San Antonio Conservation Society which prevented the demolition of the Rand Building. The agreement allowed demolition of the Stowers Building, which was razed in February 1982. The Robert E. Lee Hotel was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1996 and the Gunter Hotel was added in 2007.

Alfred Isaac Puryear was the older brother of George Wright Puryear. He served in the Stock Records Subdivision, Material Division, Supply Section, U.S. Army Air Service, throughout World War I. He stayed in the Air Service after the war, earned his pilot's wings in 1921, and became an airship pilot. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 2, page 65
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four photographs on page. Top: two photographs of the Dayton-Wright RB-1 (Dayton-Wright Racer) at the 1920 Gordon Bennett Cup race. Bottom left: Verville-Packard R-1 Racer at the 1920 Gordon Bennett Cup race. Printed on the tail is: "U.S.A. Verville Racer Air; Service U.S. Army McCook Field Dayton, Ohio." Rudolph W. Schroeder is visible standing behind the fuselage. Bottom left: Unidentified man standing next to a Breguet 14.T belonging to Compagnie des Messageries AÃ©riennes. Photo was taken at the 1920 Gordon Bennett Cup Race.

The Gordon Bennett Cup was an international airplane race created by James Gordon Bennett, Jr., owner of the "New York Herald" newspaper. It was run every year from 1909 to 1913. The 1914 race was cancelled due to the outbreak of World War I and was not run again until 1920. Rules stated that the trophy would stay with the country that won three consecutive races. Joseph Sadi-Lecointe won in 1920; it was the third consecutive time a French pilot won it, so the trophy stayed with the Aero Club de France.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "The Airman's Escape"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "The Airman's Escape" is George W. Puryear's autobiographical account of his capture and escape from a German POW camp during World War I. His account appeared in the April 1919 (p. 452-462) and May 1919 (p. 615-628) issues of Atlantic Monthly magazine. The pages were removed from the magazine and bound together into a booklet. The story is also reprinted (verbatim) as Appendix B in Harold Buckley's book "Squadron 95" (New York: Arno Press, 1972).

After completing pilot training at Issoudun and gunnery school at Cazaux, Puryear served a few months as a ferry pilot before being joining the 95th Aero Squadron on July 16, 1918. He was taken prisoner on July 26 and, after spending time in several POW camps, arrived at Villingen, Germany on September 15. Mass escape attempt made from camp on October 6. On October 11, Puryear swam across Rhine River at Waldshut, Germany to reach Switzerland, becoming first American officer in World War I to successfully escape from a German POW camp.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of southern Germany and northern Switzerland
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Map of southern Germany and northern Switzerland showing the route George W. Puryear took on his escape from the POW camp at Villingen, Germany. Villingen is circled on the map. The places where he stopped to sleep are also circled, and the date in October 1918 when he stopped there is written next to each circle. There are two X's across the Rhine from Waldshut, marking where he came out of the river and the house where he was first given aid.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "A horror picture of the war"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Graphic photograph showing most of a human skull, with skin and hair attached, sitting on a mound of earth. The photograph has a handwritten caption, "A horror picture of the war."

Both sides suffered appalling casualties on the Western Front. During the Third Battle of Ypres (1917), about 140,000 British soldiers were killed to gain five miles (or one soldier for every 2.25 inches). During the Battle of Verdun (1916), the French Army suffered 377,000 casualties and the German Army 337,000. On the first day of the Battle of the Somme (1916), the British Army suffered 60,000 casualties (roughly the population of the city of Franklin, Tennessee, in 2010).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: American Prisoners of War at Burg Trausnitz, Landshut, Germany
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Top row: Harold H. McChesney, Horace Wells, Alexander Roberts, William Tyler, James N. Hall, Henry C. Lewis, G. S. Harvey. Middle row: "Bugs" Raymond, ? Connolly, ? Hollingsworth, Alfred B. Baker, ? Whiton. Bottom row: ? White, Zenos R. Miller, Robert G. Browning, Van Winkle Todd, ? Gorman, William Kidder, ? MacElvain.

On August 19 or August 20, George W. Puryear was sent by train with eighteen British and six American POWs from Karlsruhe to Landshut, Germany. The trip took two days. The Americans were imprisoned in Burg Trausnitz (a castle dating to the 13th century). The British were imprisoned in a separate camp in town. On September 14, Puryear was transferred with nine other American officers to the camp in Villingen, arriving there on September 15. He escaped from the Villingen POW camp on the night of October 6 and reached Switzerland on October 11.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lieutenant George W. Puryear
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Studio portrait of Lieutenant George W. Puryear wearing his uniform and Sam Browne belt. His uniform displays his pilot's wings.

After completing pilot training at Issoudun and gunnery school at Cazaux, Puryear served a few months as a ferry pilot before joining the 95th Aero Squadron on July 16, 1918. He was taken prisoner on July 26 and, after spending time in several POW camps, arrived at Villingen, Germany, on September 15. On October 6, a mass escape attempt was made from camp. On October 11, Puryear swam across Rhine River at Waldshut, Germany, to reach Switzerland; he became the first American officer in World War I to successfully escape from a German POW camp.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lieutenant George W. Puryear
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lieutenant George W. Puryear standing behind a Nieuport 28 fighter plane.

Due to a shortage of American fighter planes, American fighter squadrons in France were given the French-built Nieuport 28 fighters beginning in March 1918. Due to a shortage of machine guns, the planes were equipped with only one gun each. While maneuverable and easy to fly, the Nieuport 28s had unreliable engines and were notorious for shedding the fabric on their upper wings in a steep dive. By the summer of 1918, American squadrons had replaced their Nieuport 28s with the SPAD S.XIII.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fannie Wright Puryear
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Fannie Wright Puryear wrapped in a shawl and standing in a garden.

Fannie Mildred Wright Puryear (1855-1931) married William P. Puryear (1843-1913) in Smith County, Tennessee, on February 24, 1874. William's middle name was originally Pierce, but he changed it to Pressley later in life. During the Civil War, he was a private in Company G, 9th (Ward's) Tennessee Cavalry. Fannie and William Puryear's children were Romulus, William, Daniel, David, Adolphus, Alfred, and George Puryear.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 3, page 2
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One photograph and one clipping on page. Studio (possibly Calvert) portrait of a child holding a stuffed animal. Newspaper clipping of David B. Puryear as a Representative in the Tennessee General Assembly.

David Buford Puryear (1882-1929) was the fourth of seven Puryear brothers. He represented Sumner County in the House of Representatives during the 55th, 56th, and 57th General Assemblies (1907-1912). After leaving the General Assembly, he moved to Memphis and opened a law practice there. He later became a criminal court judge and was instrumental in clearing land titles in order to create Reelfoot Lake State Park. He was also the judge in a 1917 case that led to the creation of the Memphis chapter of the NAACP.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 3, page 5
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Five photographs on page. Unidentified man hold a small boy. Alfred I. Puryear in uniform. Unidentified boy standing behind a chair. Dixona (home of Tilman Dixon) in Dixon Springs. Two unidentified women standing on a lawn next to a body of water.

Alfred I. Puryear joined the Army Air Service in 1917. He spent World War I in Paris in the Stock Records Subdivision, Material Division, Supply Section. He stayed in the Air Service after the war and qualified as an airship pilot in July 1921. He retired as a captain in 1933. Dixona was built between 1787 and 1788 by Major Tilman Dixon, a Revolutionary War soldier. The house was Smith County's first tavern and post office. In 1799, it was used for the county's first county court meeting.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 3, page 6
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: United States. Army. Armored Division, 2nd; Wedding photograph of Clayton J. Mansfield and Elsie von Hof. Clipping with information about the photograph of Clayton Mansfield on the July 22, 1940, issue of Life magazine. Photograph of (L to R) Bonnie, Clayton Mansfield, and Elsie von Hof.

Clayton John Mansfield (1906-1945) graduated from West Point in 1928. He was a member of the U.S. pentathlon team during the 1932 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles, California. He placed 13th out of twenty-five competitors. After the Olympics, he married Elsie von Hof in the chapel at Fort Riley, Kansas. He was promoted to colonel in 1944 and became the commander of the 66th Armored Regiment, 2nd Armored Division. He was killed in action during the Battle of the Bulge on January 9, 1945.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Clipping announcing that William P. Puryear Jr., had won the election for mayor of Gallatin. Clipping announcing the upcoming wedding of Cornelia Puryear to William P. Weisiger.

William P. Puryear Jr. (1907-1981), graduated from Cumberland University Law School in 1929. He served as mayor of Gallatin from 1942 to 1948. He was president of the Gallatin Rotary Club in 1948 and was a judge for the 9th Circuit from; 1952 to 1965. Cornelia Puryear was the daughter of Gustavus Adolphus Puryear and Cornelia Libby Puryear. She graduated from Vanderbilt University with a B.A. in English in 1938. She married William P. Weisiger on November 11, 1938.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 3, page 10
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Brochure for the Granada Apartment Hotel.

On May 25, 1935, Alfred I. Puryear sailed aboard the S.S. Virginia from San Francisco, via the Panama Canal and Havana, Cuba, to New York. It is possible that the ship also stopped in Miami and that these clippings date from that trip. The Granada Apartment Hotel was built in the Fort Dallas Park neighborhood of Miami, Florida, in 1922. It was Miami's first condominium building. It was demolished on April 21, 1973.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Official report of Alfred I. Puryear's solo flight in an airship from Ross Field to Glendora, California.

Ross Field in Arcadia was the site of an Army Balloon School. Alfred Pruyrear went to balloon school there, beginning in either late 1920 or early 1921. From 1922 to 1928, he was transferred back and forth between Scott Field, Belleville, Illinois, and Langley Field, Virginia. In February 1928, he became commander of the 19th Airship Company at Langley Field. In June 1930, he became commander of the 2nd Balloon Company, Fort Bragg, North Carolina. He retired from the Air Service on November 30, 1933.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 3, page 22
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Studio portrait of David B. Puryear.

David Buford Puryear (1882-1929) was the 4th of 7 Puryear brothers. He represented Sumner County in the House of Representatives during the 55th, 56th, and 57th General Assemblies (1907-1912). After leaving the General Assembly, he moved to Memphis and; opened a law practice there. He later became a criminal court judge and was instrumental in clearing land titles in order to create Reelfoot Lake State Park. He was also the judge in a 1917 case that led to the creation of the Memphis chapter of the NAACP.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 3, page 23
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Studio portrait of Alfred I. Puryear.

Alfred received his initial training in the coastal artillery, but at some point between November 1917 and January 1918 he transferred to the Air Service. In January 1918, he joined the Stock Records Subdivision, Material Division, Supply Section, Army Air Service, in Paris, where he remained throughout the war. He left to return to the U.S. aboard the U.S.S. Agamemnon on September 16, 1919. He remained in the Air Service after the war, became an airship pilot, and retired in 1933.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 3, page 24
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Six photographs on page. Group of unidentified men sitting on some steps. Alfred I. Puryear (in uniform) with his mother, Fannie Wright Puryear. Unidentified man holding an unidentified infant. Fannie W. Puryear standing outside the U.S. Capitol. Fannie W. Puryear standing on a lawn. Either George W. or Alfred I. Puryear wearing a bathing suit and standing next to three unidentified women and an unidentified man (possibly taken in San Diego).

After returning from France in September 1919, Alfred I. Puryear served in the office of the Chief of the Air Service. The Air Service was headquartered in the Munitions Building on Constitution Avenue in Washington, D.C. It remained there until construction of the Pentagon was completed in 1943. The building was demolished in 1970, and the site is now occupied by the Vietnam Veterans Memorial.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Studio portrait of an unidentified man in a U. S. Army Air Corps uniform. There are cadet patches on the lapels of his jacket, and he is wearing a Sam Browne belt.

The Army Air Service was renamed the Army Air Corps on July 2, 1926. On June 20, 1941, it was renamed again and became the Army Air Forces. On September 18, 1947, it became a separate branch of the military and has been the U.S. Air Force ever since.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 3, page 27
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One photograph and one clipping on page. Four people sitting on benches on a porch. On the left is an unidentified woman holding an unidentified infant. On the right is possibly George W. Puryear as a boy, Fannie W. Puryear sits at his left. The clipping is a photograph of the prisoner of war camp where George W. Puryear was being held at the time of his 1918 escape.

George W. Puryear joined the 95th Aero Squadron on July 16, 1918. He was taken prisoner on July 26. He escaped from the POW camp at Villingen, Germany, on October 6 and swam across the Rhine River at Landshut, Germany, on October 11. The feat made him the first American officer in World War I to successfully escape from a German POW camp. After returning to the U.S., he was stationed at Rockwell Field, San Diego, California. He was killed on October 20, 1919, when his plane crashed shortly after take off.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 3, page 29
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of the Puryear family graves in Gallatin Cemetery festooned with funeral wreaths. The large headstone in the center is possibly marks the grave of William Pressley Puryear (1843-1913). To the right is George W. Puryear's grave (at the; foot is a small sign which reads "G. W. P."). While the photograph appears to be taken in spring/summer, given the climate of Middle Tennessee, it is possible that it was taken in October 1919 shortly after George's burial.

George W. Puryear was assigned to the 9th Aero Squadron at Rockwell Field, San Diego, Calif., soon after returning to the U.S. from World War I. He was killed on October 20, 1919, when his plane crashed shortly after take off. His body arrived via train in Memphis on October 27 and was escorted to the home of his brother David. It was then sent to Gallatin for burial on October 28. An article in the October 28, 1919 issue of The Tennessean newspaper describes the procession in Memphis from the train station to David's house.
