oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 3, page 30
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Five color clippings of various sites around Miami, Fla. Top middle and bottom left clippings show the Granada Apartment Hotel in Fort Dallas Park along the Miami River.

On May 25, 1935, Alfred I. Puryear sailed aboard the S.S. Virginia from San Francisco, via the Panama Canal and Havana, Cuba, to New York. It is possible that the ship also stopped in Miami and that these clippings date from that trip. The Granada Apartment Hotel was built in the Fort Dallas Park neighborhood of Miami, Florida, in 1922. It was Miami's first condominium building. It was demolished on April 21, 1973.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Panoramic photograph of OrlÃ©ans, France, showing the Pont George V over the Loire River and the Basilique CathÃ©drale Sainte-Croix d'OrlÃ©ans in the background. A horse and cart and a streetcar are visible on the bridge.

In January 1918, Alfred I. Puryear joined the Stock Records Subdivision, Material Division, Supply Section, Army Air Service, in Paris. Alfred may have acquired the photograph in OrlÃ©ans during the time he was travelling between Paris and Tours.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 3, page 34
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of the U.S.S. Agamemnon bringing troops home from Europe (possibly showing New York Harbor). A tugboat is approaching the ship, and its decks and rigging are crowded with soldiers.

Alfred Puryear left for Europe aboard the Adriatic on December 25, 1917. His voyage home aboard the Agamemnon began on September 16, 1919. The Agamemnon was built in 1903 as the S.S. Kaiser Wilhelm II and was operated by Norddeutscher Lloyd. After the U.S. declared war on Germany in April 1917, the ship was seized and renamed the Agamemnon that September.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four photographs of Mt. Wilson north of Arcadia, California.

Ross Field in Arcadia was the site of an Army Balloon School. Some sources list the school as closing in 1919, but photographs and documents in Albums 2 and 3 show that it was still in operation as late as 1921. Alfred Pruyrear went to balloon school there, beginning in either late 1920 or early 1921. He made his first solo flight on July 8, 1921, flying from Arcadia to Glendora, California.

In June 1930, Alfred I. Puryear was transferred from the 19th Airship Company, Langley Field, Virginia, to the 2nd Balloon Company, Fort Bragg, North Carolina. The December 4, 1931, issue of the "Air Corps News Letter" lists him as the commanding officer of the 2nd Balloon Company. On November 30, 1933, he retired from the Army Air Corps with the rank of captain.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 3, page 39
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Copy of official Army Air Service incident report related to George W. Puryear's capture. Report lists the date, time, and location of his capture as 7:20 a.m. on July 26, 1918, near Villeneuve-sur-FÃ¨re (about 13 miles northeast of ChÃ¢teau-Thierry). Report also lists the type and serial number of his airplane and his airplane's motor.

On July 16, 1918, George Puryear, Irby Curry, and three others joined the 95th Aero Squadron at Saints, France. George was captured on July 26, 1918 after he shot down a German airplane and mistakenly landed behind enemy lines. He had intended to take prisoners. After transfer to several POW camps, Puryear ended up in Villingen, Germany. He escaped on October 6 and swam across the Rhine River into Switzerland on October 11. He was the first American officer to successfully escape from a German POW camp during World War I.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Puryear Album 3, page 40
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Undated draft report by Alfred I. Puryear on an airship flight from Scott Field, Belleville, Illinois, to Sulphur Springs, Missouri. The report contains handwritten edits.

After completing his training to become an airship pilot in July 1921, Alfred Puryear was transferred to Scott Field in June 1922. Between 1924 and 1926, he appears to have been transferred back and forth between Scott Field and Langley Field, Virginia. In June 1926, he was assigned to the 19th Airship Company at Langley Field and became its commanding officer in February 1928. In June 1930, he was transferred from the 19th Airship Company to the 2nd Balloon Company, Fort Bragg, North Carolina and was its commanding officer. He retired November 30, 1933.

Alfred I. Puryear served with the Stock Records Subdivision, Material Division, Supply Section, U.S. Army Air Service, in Paris, France, during World War I. He returned home in September 1919 and stayed in the Air Service after the war. He completed his training and; became an airship pilot in July 1921. He was promoted to captain on January 17, 1929. Towards the end of his career, he was commanding officer of the 19th Airship Company and the 2nd Balloon Company. He retired on November 30, 1933.
